import os
# === Parameters from pipeline ===
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

from notebookutils import mssparkutils

import os
# === Parameters from pipeline ===
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

from notebookutils import mssparkutils


# --------------------------
# Manual defaults for testing
# --------------------------
# Python notebook code

# Get notebook parameter safely
# Retrieve the notebook parameter from pipeline
file_name = mssparkutils.notebook.getParameter("fileName", "Florida-10102025.csv")

print("file_name =", file_name)

print("Received file name:", file_name)

# Auto-extract state and date from filename (very common pattern)
state_name = file_name.split('-')[0]          # "Florida" → you can map to "FL" if needed
file_date  = file_name.split('-')[1].replace('.csv', '')  # "10102025.csv" → "20251010"

# Optional: map state name to abbreviation
state_map = {"Florida": "FL", "California": "CA", "Texas": "TX"}
state_name = state_map.get(state_name, state_name[:2].upper())

print(f"Auto-detected → {file_name} | {state_name} | {file_date}")

# Optional for JDBC URL if using environment variables or pipeline
# dbutils.widgets.text("jdbcUrl", "")
# dbutils.widgets.text("targetTable", "")

#targetDB


#jdbc_url     = os.environ.get("SQL_JDBC_URL")
#target_table = os.environ.get("SQL_TABLE")
# === ADLS configuration ===
container = "synapse1"
account = "alexanalytics1"  # without .dfs.core.windows.net
folder = "synapse/workspaces/alex-analytics1"
file_path = f"abfss://{container}@{account}.dfs.core.windows.net/{folder}/{file_name}"

# === Read CSV with schema inferred ===
df = (spark.read
      .option("header", "true")
      .option("inferSchema", "true")
      .option("quote", '"')
      .option("escape", '\\')
      .csv(file_path))
print("Read CSV File")
df.show()



# === SQL Server connection ===
jdbc_url = "jdbc:sqlserver://dths-test-sqlserver.database.windows.net:1433;databaseName=dths"
target_table = "dbo.batches"

# Get token using notebook's Managed Identity (automatic)
token = mssparkutils.credentials.getToken('dw')

connectionProperties = {
    "accessToken": token,
    "driver": "com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver"
}
# === Write to SQL Server efficiently ===
# Replace "BatchID" since it's the INSERT_IDENTITY column
df_to_write = df.drop("BatchID")

# Then write
(df_to_write.write
   .format("jdbc")
   .mode("append")
   .option("url", jdbc_url)
   .option("dbtable", "dbo.batches")
   .option("batchsize", "10000")
   .options(**connectionProperties)
   .save())

print(f"Data successfully written to {target_table}")

# === Archive processed file ===
source_path = f"{folder}/{file_name}"
archive_path = f"{folder}/archive/{file_name}"
mssparkutils.fs.mkdirs(f"abfss://{container}@{account}.dfs.core.windows.net/{folder}/archive")
mssparkutils.fs.mv(
    f"abfss://{container}@{account}.dfs.core.windows.net/{source_path}",
    f"abfss://{container}@{account}.dfs.core.windows.net/{archive_path}"
)
print(f"Moved file to archive: {archive_path}")

# Get token using notebook's Managed Identity (automatic)
token = mssparkutils.credentials.getToken('dw')

# JDBC connection to Azure SQL
server = "dths-test-sqlserver.database.windows.net"
database = "dths"
table = "dbo.batches"

jdbcUrl = f"jdbc:sqlserver://{server}:1433;database={database}";

connectionProperties = {
    "accessToken": token,
    "driver": "com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver"
}

df = spark.read.jdbc(url=jdbcUrl, table=table, properties=connectionProperties)
df.show()
